author: By Santul Nerkar
title: $7 Million for 30 Seconds? To Advertisers, the Super Bowl Is Worth It.
description: In a time of fragmentation, advertising during the game’s broadcast is still a reliable way to boost company revenue and familiarize viewers with a brand.
content: A cat meowing for Hellmann’s mayonnaise, Peyton Manning chucking Bud Light beers to patrons in a bar and Kris Jenner stacking Oreo cookies. They all have one thing in common: Those companies paid seven figures to get their products in front of viewers during this year’s Super Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: ‘Ghetto Fabulous’ on the Red Carpet
description: A major moment at the Grammys showed how far Baby Phat, the streetwear brand, has come — and how it helped change what constitutes high fashion.
content: Ice Spice was born on Jan. 1, 2000, so it seems fitting that her personal style has often involved Y2K fashion. The rapper leaned heavily into the era at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, wearing custom Baby Phat. She arrived in a fur-lined denim jacket and a matching maxi skirt that trailed behind her as she walked the red carpet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump, Immigration and the Lump of Labor Fallacy
description: Neither machines nor immigrants take away Americans’ jobs.
content: What did Kurt Vonnegut, the novelist, and François Mitterrand, the socialist president of France from 1981 to 1995, have in common with Donald Trump? Both, at some point, believed in what economists call the lump of labor fallacy. This is the view that there is a fixed amount of work to be done and that if someone or something — some group of workers or some kind of machine — is doing some of that work, that means fewer jobs for everyone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Patrick Kingsley, Rikki Novetsky, Will Reid, Sydney Harper, Mooj Zadie, Paige Cowett, M.J. Davis Lin, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: The U.N. Scandal Threatening Crucial Aid to Gaza
description: Major donors including the United States have suspended funding to the main United Nations relief agency in Gaza.
content: Late last month, an explosive allegation that workers from a crucial U.N. relief agency in Gaza had taken part in the Oct. 7 attacks stunned the world and prompted major donors, including the United States, to suspend funding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Cool Thing to Wear to the Big Game? Something Old.
description: Vintage sportswear is resonating with fans who don’t want to look like everyone else. (Yes, Taylor Swift is involved.)
content: The team store: A glorified souvenir shop at stadiums and arenas, where sports fans shop for official jerseys, snapback hats and a variety of magnets and key chains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Mother of Michigan Gunman Found Guilty of Manslaughter
description: Jennifer Crumbley was convicted on four counts of involuntary manslaughter, one for each student her son killed in Michigan’s deadliest school shooting.
content: Michigan jurors, after 11 hours of deliberations, found Jennifer Crumbley guilty of involuntary manslaughter on Tuesday for the gun rampage committed by her teenage son, who carried out the state’s deadliest school shooting more than two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aric Toler, Sarah Kerr, Adam Sella, Arijeta Lajka and Chevaz Clarke
title: What Israeli Soldiers’ Videos Reveal: Cheering Destruction and Mocking Gazans
description: An analysis of social media videos found Israeli soldiers filming themselves in Gaza and destroying what appears to be civilian property. The footage provides a rare and unsanctioned window into the war.
content: An Israeli soldier gives a thumbs up to the camera as he drives a bulldozer down a street in Beit Lahia, in northern Gaza, pushing a battered car toward a half-collapsed building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Snap Shares Plummet After First-Quarter Guidance Disappoints
description: The Snapchat parent company’s revenue for the fourth quarter was up from a year earlier, but it missed Wall Street’s expectations on spending.
content: Snap’s stock fell more than 30 percent in after-hours trading on Tuesday after its guidance fell short of analyst expectations even as the company reported a 5 percent increase in revenue, its second straight quarter of growth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: Why One Shaky Bank Is Stirring Fears of a Wider Financial Mess
description: New York Community Bancorp’s plunging stock price highlights risks that loom over lenders large and small.
content: As the one-year anniversary of a crisis that brought down several midsize banks approaches, trouble at another lender is putting unwelcome attention on the industry again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Safak Timur
title: A Year After a Devastating Quake: Container Cities, Trials and Grief
description: On the anniversary of a catastrophic earthquake, Turkey is still struggling to rebuild, help survivors and hold people responsible for shoddy construction.
content: At 4:17 a.m. on Tuesday, thousands of people in cities across southern Turkey gathered to cry, light candles and chant against the government, marking the moment a year ago that a powerful earthquake devastated the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: King Pushed for Transparency on Diagnosis. He Raised Questions in the Process.
description: The king has let people know more about his health than other monarchs, but a decision to keep private the form of cancer he has is leading to speculation in lieu of facts.
content: When Buckingham Palace announced on Monday that King Charles III had been diagnosed with cancer and would halt his public engagements to undergo treatment, it predictably set off a storm of questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bina Shah
title: Pakistanis Like Me Are Losing Faith in Democracy
description: There’s a sense of global disillusionment with democracy’s undelivered promises. In Pakistan, that’s our default setting.
content: This is a critical week for Pakistanis. On Thursday we will vote in federal and provincial elections, with the future of our democracy in question. We are not the only country facing such a moment this year. National elections will be held in more than 60 countries, which account for nearly half the global population.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Close at Hand
description: Victor Barocas takes a detour.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Ex-Doctor Charged With Manslaughter in New York Woman’s Suicide
description: The police provided few details about the death, making it unclear whether it would be covered by the medical aid in dying laws that some states have but that New York does not.
content: A former doctor from Arizona is facing a manslaughter charge in New York for his role in the suicide of a woman who died in a Hudson Valley motel room in November, according to his lawyer and law enforcement officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: No, Border Deal Won’t ‘Allow’ 5,000 Unauthorized Immigrants a Day
description: Republican critics are misrepresenting one provision of a bipartisan deal to suggest that it permits 5,000 illegal crossings a day.
content: Republican critics have quickly twisted one element of a bipartisan compromise bill unveiled on Sunday to misleadingly suggest that it permits 5,000 migrants to enter the country illegally every day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde McGrady
title: From Ferguson to Gaza: How African Americans Bonded With Palestinian Activists
description: The relationship became closer during protests over police brutality, but brings political risks, like straining the alliance between African Americans and Jews.
content: One hot Saturday in August 2014, Sandra Tamari scrolled through social media and learned that a Black teenager named Michael Brown had been  fatally shot by a police officer in nearby Ferguson, Mo. Her heart “just sank,” she recalled, when she learned that Mr. Brown’s mother had stood on the other side of the police tape while her son’s body had been lying in the street for hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims
title: A Last-Minute Trip to What May Be the Priciest Super Bowl Ever: Around $9,859 Per Person
description: Thinking of a splurge to see the big game in Las Vegas this weekend? You’ll be competing with billionaires who are going to “have trouble parking their planes.”
content: So you want to go to the Super Bowl this weekend. Even for non-football fans, this year’s spectacle of professional sports and over-the-top entertainment — in Las Vegas, no less — could be hard to resist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins
title: What’s the Best Way to Clean Your Ears?
description: Cotton swabs may feel the most satisfying, but there are safer and more effective alternatives.
content: Q: I know I’m not supposed to stick things like Q-Tips in my ears. But how else am I supposed to clean them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: State Department Security Officer Charged in Jan. 6 Attack on Capitol
description: Kevin Michael Alstrup was arrested on Tuesday for participating in the breach in 2021. He was familiar with providing protection for high-ranking officials and sensitive locations, the F.B.I. said.
content: A security officer who had worked as a contractor for the State Department was arrested on federal charges on Tuesday in connection with his participation in the breach of the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: President of Powerful Service Workers Union Will Step Down
description: Mary Kay Henry of the nearly two-million-member Service Employees International Union will not seek re-election when her term ends in May.
content: Mary Kay Henry, the president of the Service Employees International Union, one of the nation’s largest and most politically powerful labor unions, announced Tuesday that she would step down after 14 years in her position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: King Charles is diagnosed with cancer.
content: Less than 18 months into his reign, Britain’s King Charles III has been diagnosed with cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: Explaining a Major Education Settlement in California
description: The state has agreed to use at least $2 billion meant for pandemic recovery to help students hurt most by remote learning.
content: The State of California settled a lawsuit last week that had been going on for more than three years, since the height of the debate around pandemic school closures. The case was notable nationally; there have been few others like it. And the settlement included an eye-popping number: $2 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hal Sundt
title: I’ve Never Bought Anything From QVC. I Can’t Stop Watching It.
description: The playful pleasures of David Venable keep pulling me back in.
content: Last fall, I lived in a hotel in the small college town where I teach, an admittedly strange arrangement that came with a serendipitous perk: cable TV. At the end of most days, after stocking up on ice from the machine down the hall, I would get beneath the sheets and click on QVC. If I was lucky, I got to watch the incomparable David Venable, whose most distinct trait — aside from his striking height (6 feet 6 inches) and the dulcet tones of his North Carolina drawl — is his “happy dance”: a hands-over-head, 360-degree twirl that he executes when a product especially delights him. In seemingly every moment of his cooking and housewares show, “In the Kitchen With David,” he radiates joie de vivre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: sacrosanct
description: This word has appeared in 50 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word sacrosanct has appeared in 50 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 19 in “A Famed Cemetery Is Nearly Full. Can It Reuse Old Graves to Add More Space?” by Isabella Kwai:

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Banks Sue Regulators Over Anti-Redlining Rule
description: A new lawsuit says federal agencies overstepped their authority in a rule forcing banks to do business in underserved communities.
content: Some of the banking industry’s most powerful trade groups sued the Federal Reserve, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency on Monday, claiming that the regulators overstepped their authority in updating a law meant to reverse the effects of redlining.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Readers discuss the surge of migrants seeking asylum in the U.S. Also: Palestinian suffering and Israeli dilemmas; the moon’s mystique.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: What’s Next in the Federal Election Case Against Trump?
description: The question of when — or whether — the former president faces trial for trying to overturn the 2020 election could hinge on how the Supreme Court handles his appeal of the decision denying his immunity claim.
content: The ruling on Tuesday by a three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in Washington rejecting former President Donald J. Trump’s claims of immunity against charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election was a significant defeat for Mr. Trump. And it was a win for Jack Smith, the special counsel, who has been trying to keep the case moving along at a pace that would allow it to go to trial well before Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag, William K. Rashbaum and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Prominent N.Y. Developer Arrested on Charges Tied to Vast Fraud Scheme
description: Nir Meir helped run the firm HFZ Capital Group, which became a major developer of luxury housing but collapsed amid investor lawsuits and foreclosures.
content: A former executive at a prominent New York City development firm that collapsed amid an avalanche of investor lawsuits and foreclosures was arrested this week and is expected to be charged in connection with a multimillion-dollar fraud scheme, according to several people with knowledge of the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Heather Knight
title: Where Has Tracy Chapman Been?
description: Her triumphant performance at the Grammy Awards left fans wondering what she has been doing since she left the music world, and whether she might return.
content: Tracy Chapman’s rare public appearance at the Grammy Awards on Sunday night — where she practically stole the show performing her 1988 song “Fast Car” with the country singer Luke Combs — left many fans wondering why she had largely stepped away from music for more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Saiyna Bashir
title: Discontent and Defiance on the Road to Pakistan’s Election
description: The Grand Trunk Road is buzzing with talk of the coming vote, and of the country’s future.
content: The highway is the most politically charged slice of a politically turbulent country. It winds 180 miles from Pakistan’s capital, Islamabad, through the fertile plains of Punjab Province to Lahore, the nation’s cultural and political heart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: The Changing Focus of Climate Denial: From Science to Scientists
description: The scientist Michael Mann is challenging attacks on his work in a defamation suit that’s taken 12 years to come to trial.
content: One July morning in 2012, climate scientist Michael Mann woke up to a terse email from a fellow scientist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Biden Has Openings for a Comeback on Two Weak Points
description: He now has a clear line of defense on the border issue and a strong argument about the economy.
content: President Biden’s approval ratings are as low as ever. An NBC poll this weekend was only the latest example, showing him trailing Donald J. Trump by five percentage points nationwide, with his approval down to 37 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember and Mark Walker
title: Alaska Airlines 737 May Have Left Boeing Factory Missing Bolts, N.T.S.B. Says
description: A photo indicates that bolts in a fuselage panel were removed at a Boeing factory and not replaced, the National Transportation Safety Board said.
content: Four bolts used to secure the panel that ultimately blew off an Alaska Airlines plane during a flight last month were removed — and appear not to have been replaced — at Boeing’s factory in Renton, Wash., according to a preliminary report released Tuesday by the National Transportation Safety Board.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Prison Escapes, Indefinite Lockdowns and Distress Signals Left in the Lurch
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 6, 2024.
content: “They’re not going to take us seriously until somebody gets killed.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: What Is Mild Cognitive Impairment, and How Is It Diagnosed?
description: Doctors explain the signs to look for, and how to get evaluated.
content: Mike Davis’s mother died from Alzheimer’s disease in 2008. So when Mr. Davis started noticing that he was having an increasing number of “senior moments” at age 76 — such as forgetting to water his plants, something he was normally regimented about — he decided to have his cognition tested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Rutter
title: An Airborne Toxic Event Plagues an Aboriginal Town in This Novel
description: “Praiseworthy,” Alexis Wright’s bracing satire of clashing worldviews in Australia, more than lives up to its name.
content: The fictional town of Praiseworthy, the setting of Alexis Wright’s hypnotic new novel of the same name, is home to the Steel family, who live on disputed Native title land in Australia’s Northern Territory. From the book’s opening — “Once upon a fine time for some people in the world” — we sense the jagged discord of competing realities, of something ancient or timeless searching for its place in the modern world, like a crocodile in a swimming pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: A Mild Cognitive Impairment Diagnosis Can Be Scary. Here’s What Comes Next.
description: There are ways to manage symptoms and slow the progression.
content: Cognitive decline is a frightening prospect for most people. But experts say there are ways to manage and treat it, especially if it’s caught at an early stage, known as mild cognitive impairment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: A New Creature Emerges From a Forest Drowned by the Gulf of Mexico
description: Scientists discovered a species off the Alabama coast that is part of group of mussels never before seen at such shallow depths.
content: The creature was tiny, about the size and color of a grain of rice. Dan Distel, director of the Ocean Genome Legacy Center at Northeastern University in Boston, wasn’t exactly sure what it was, other than a mussel of some kind. He put the wee bivalve in a petri dish and asked a colleague to set it aside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul McAdory
title: Rising From the Dead at Monster Jam
description: A rapt crowd watched as Grave Digger, Zombie and other monster trucks soared through the air and crashed to the ground.
content: At a recent Monster Jam event at the Prudential Center in Newark, as shark-finned and dog-eared and zombie-limbed monster trucks careened around a stadium floor caked in doughy, cinnamon-brown dirt, I remembered the first pseudo-sentence I ever spoke: “Big truck go by.” Gaggles of young children wiggled around the stands, their mouths agape and their ears covered by muffs or a parent’s palms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Keith McNally’s Filmmaking Past Is Forgotten No More
description: Hundreds of moviegoers went to rare screenings of the New York restaurateur’s little-known 1990 film. Afterward, he treated them to half-price dinners at Balthazar and Minetta Tavern.
content: On Thursday night at the Roxy Cinema in Lower Manhattan, a throng of scarf-bundled cinephiles attended the sold-out screening of a black-and-white psychological thriller, “End of the Night,” that was being shown for the first time in more than 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: A Super Bowl Broadcaster With Slime and Swagger
description: Nate Burleson spent 11 seasons playing in the N.F.L. He now balances several TV assignments, and will announce the Super Bowl with SpongeBob SquarePants.
content: Nate Burleson, far removed from the 11 seasons he spent toiling in the National Football League, pulled up his shirt to wipe sweat from his forehead during a well-deserved break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Rachel Shorey
title: Trucker Hats and Ice Cream: The Most Surprising Ways Candidates Spent Cash
description: Political candidates in 2023 shelled out donors’ money for a variety of unusual expenses, including gift cards, hairstyling and frozen treats, new filings revealed.
content: How political candidates spend their cash can say a lot about them: their instincts, their attention to detail, their care with money or lack thereof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Bintliff and Josh Holder
title: King Charles Has Cancer. Here’s What to Know.
description: The British monarch’s diagnosis was a surprise announcement. Here’s a guide to the news and its potential implications.
content: On Monday night, Buckingham Palace made a sudden announcement that King Charles III had been diagnosed with cancer, less than 18 months after beginning his reign. He is receiving outpatient treatment in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: WeWork’s Co-Founder Is Trying to Buy the Company
description: Adam Neumann, the co-working company’s onetime chief, has sought for months to buy the now-bankrupt business, but accuses its current leaders of stonewalling him.
content: Adam Neumann shot to fame by turning WeWork into a cultural and business phenomenon, before being ousted from the work space operator in dramatic fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg and Rafal Milach
title: In Poland, I Saw What a Second Trump Term Could Do to America
description: Being in Warsaw was inspiring and sobering.
content: Adam Bodnar, Poland’s new justice minister, recently explained to me the immense challenge of rebuilding liberal democracy in his country after an eight-year slide toward authoritarianism. Imagine, he said, that Donald Trump had won the last election and been in power for two terms instead of one. “What would be the damage?” he asked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan, Shawn Hubler and Corina Knoll
title: In Los Angeles, a Growing Sense That ‘Historic’ Weather Is Becoming Normal
description: With the latest atmospheric river dumping nearly a foot of rain on some neighborhoods, residents are becoming used to living with dire warnings and extreme conditions.
content: Californians have long joked that their state has three seasons: wildfire, earthquake and flood. But as an atmospheric river parked itself over Los Angeles this week, knocking out power and dumping record rainfall, there was a serious coming to terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Mady Camara
title: Senegal Parliament Delays Elections Until December After Opposition Showdown
description: President Macky Sall abruptly postponed elections scheduled for this month, and on Monday, legislators in the West African nation voted to allow him to stay in office months after his presidency is to end.
content: Senegal’s Parliament voted late Monday to delay elections until December, after opposition lawmakers seeking to block the vote were thrown out of the National Assembly. The vote came after President Macky Sall last week postponed the upcoming ballot, a move critics condemned as an “institutional coup.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Charles III’s Cancer Diagnosis Could Reshape How the Monarchy Works
description: Britain’s king has been a highly visible royal, making hundreds of public appearances. As he steps back from view, who will fill the gap?
content: Queen Elizabeth II liked to say that she needed to be seen to be believed. Now it falls to her son King Charles III to test that principle, after a cancer diagnosis that will force him out of the public eye for the foreseeable future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Dozens of House Republicans Declare Trump’s Jan. 6 Actions Were Not Insurrection
description: More than 60 lawmakers signed onto the declaration as courts and state elections officials weigh whether the former president is eligible to hold office under the 14th Amendment.
content: As officials across the country consider whether to bar former President Donald J. Trump from the ballot over his role in the events of Jan. 6, 2021, a contingent of House Republicans are trying to bolster his claim that he did nothing wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: When Mental Health Treatment Becomes a Political Identity
description: Lina Hidalgo, a rising Democratic star in Houston, earned praise for openly discussing her struggles with depression. Is such honesty still a political risk?
content: As a rising young Democratic star and the top elected official of Harris County, the most populous in Texas, Lina Hidalgo surprised many people last summer when she announced that she had checked herself in at a residential mental health clinic for serious depression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Elisa Gutierrez and Jennifer Medina
title: Why Donald Trump Won Nevada Before Any Votes Were Cast
description: Winning over Latino voters is going to be crucial to taking the battleground in November, and Trump seems to have an early advantage.
content: Nevada is doing things differently this year. Or at least, it tried to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Peace in Ukraine
description: What a Ukraine peace deal might look like.
content: Last year’s Ukrainian counteroffensive was a failure. Russia’s defenses in the territory it has captured look impenetrable. Republicans in Washington are blocking further Ukraine aid. President Volodymyr Zelensky is on the precipice of firing his top general — who may well become his chief political rival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: What Relationships Would You Want if You Believed They Were Possible?
description: Rhaina Cohen makes a case for expanding the role of friendship in our lives.
content: Around 40 percent of people who marry eventually get a divorce. Almost half of children are born to unmarried women. The number of close friends Americans report having has been on a steep decline since the 1990s, especially among men. Millions of us are growing old alone. We are living out a radical experiment in how we live, love, parent and age — and for many, it’s failing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Robert Spano to Lead Washington National Opera as Music Director
description: The veteran conductor, who won acclaim as a champion of new music at the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, will begin a three-year term in 2025.
content: The conductor Robert Spano, who won acclaim as a champion of contemporary music during his two decades at the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, will serve as Washington National Opera’s next music director, the company announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Rhaina Cohen
description: The Feb. 6, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Rhaina Cohen. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Was Your Most Memorable Field Trip?
description: What have you learned from excursions outside of the classroom?
content: Have you ever taken a field trip that broadened your horizons, or taught you something that you would never have learned from a textbook? Perhaps you went to a planetarium, or a history museum or a play? Or maybe you just took a class trip that was really fun?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Olivia Bensimon
title: Columbia Limited Campus Protests, So Students Took to the Streets
description: As Columbia and Barnard weigh how to protect free speech and student safety, their protest rules have forced some students off campus, where they have clashed with the police.
content: The steps in front of Low Memorial Library at Columbia University have been the site of major campus protests since the 1960s. But when pro-Palestinian demonstrators tried to organize a rally there last Thursday, the area was barricaded off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: Federal Records Show Increasing Use of Solitary Confinement for Immigrants
description: A new report based on records from the Trump and Biden years found the average length of solitary detainment was longer than the duration the U.N. says can constitute torture.
content: The United States government has placed detained immigrants in solitary confinement more than 14,000 times in the last five years, and the average duration is almost twice the 15-day threshold that the United Nations has said may constitute torture, according to a new analysis of federal records by researchers at Harvard and the nonprofit group Physicians for Human Rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Cancer Diagnosis Like King Charles’s Is Not Unheard-Of
description: While Buckingham Palace released little information on Charles’s diagnosis, some cancer experts not involved in his care have seen the illness detected during other routine medical procedures.
content: A patient checks into the hospital for a routine procedure to treat an enlarged prostate. And, unexpectedly, a test done in the hospital — perhaps a blood test or an X-ray or an examination of the urethra and the bladder — finds a cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley, Mihir Zaveri and Corey Kilgannon
title: Scores of N.Y. Public Housing Workers Charged in Record Corruption Case
description: Manhattan’s federal prosecutor said the number of bribery charges, 70 in all, amounted to a single-day record for the Justice Department.
content: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan unsealed bribery and extortion charges on Tuesday against 70 current and former employees of the New York City Housing Authority, a sweeping accusation of malfeasance in a troubled organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Pascale Bonnefoy
title: Former Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Dies in Helicopter Crash
description: Mr. Piñera was a billionaire businessman who served two terms, leaving office in 2022.
content: Sebastián Piñera, a former president of Chile who helped strengthen the nation’s young democracy after becoming its first conservative leader since a military dictatorship, died in a helicopter crash in Chile on Tuesday, the government said. He was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Nevada’s Weird Election Week, and King Charles’s Cancer
description: Plus, Tucker Carlson spotted in Moscow.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: A Russian Bank Account May Offer Clues to a North Korean Arms Deal
description: Moscow may be trying to help Pyongyang with access to the international financial system in exchange for missiles and ammunition, U.S.-allied intelligence officials suggest.
content: Russia has allowed the release of millions of dollars in frozen North Korean assets and may be helping its isolated ally with access to international banking networks, assistance that has come after the North’s transfer of weapons to Moscow for use against Ukraine, according to American-allied intelligence officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Ziegler and Jillian Weinberger
title: A Second Trump Term Could Lead to a ‘Backdoor Federal Abortion Ban’
description: The future of reproductive rights in America may hinge on the next election.
content: With Donald Trump seemingly unstoppable in his bid for the Republican presidential nomination, the law professor Mary Ziegler considers what a second Trump term would mean for abortion rights. In this audio essay, she argues that while Trump may seem indifferent on the campaign trail to tightening abortion laws, there is a real possibility that if re-elected he will seek to appease his base by using his executive power to ban abortions nationwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Los Angeles Works to Build Its Dance Muscles
description: Companies are cropping up and expanding. Is the city on the cusp of a fertile chapter in its dance history?
content: Los Angeles may not be thought of as a dance town, but it has a rich legacy. It was here, in 1915, that the modern dance pioneers Ruth St. Denis and her husband Ted Shawn, established the Denishawn school and company, shaping and showcasing the first generation of American modern dancers, including Martha Graham, Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Kevin Draper
title: Disney, Fox and Warner Bros. Join Forces for Sports Streaming Service
description: The move takes aim at a major issue for media companies as viewers abandon cable and prices soar for broadcast rights to sporting events.
content: For years, the rising price of sports rights has been a major headache for media executives, who have watched viewers abandon traditional TV for streaming services even as their companies continue to pay up to broadcast games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: NASA Spots Signs of Twin Volcanic Plumes on Jupiter’s Moon Io
description: The second of a pair of close flybys adds to the treasure trove of data that scientists have about Jupiter’s volcanic moon.
content: On Saturday, NASA’s Juno orbiter got a second close-up with Io, Jupiter’s third-largest moon and the most volcanic world of our solar system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Says Ronna McDaniel ‘Knows’ She Should Step Down as R.N.C. Chair
description: The former president also signaled that he could call for changes at the Republican National Committee soon after the South Carolina primary on Feb. 24.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump on Monday suggested that Ronna McDaniel should leave her post as chairwoman of the Republican National Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: A Legal Blow to Trump
description: Plus, a Korean food renaissance in New York.
content: A federal appeals court rejected Donald Trump’s claim of absolute immunity in a criminal indictment accusing him of plotting to overturn the 2020 election. The court ruled that he was subject to federal criminal law — like any other American — and must stand trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Kenna
title: How to Take Better Pictures With a Drone
description: Simply using a drone doesn’t mean you can shoot excellent aerial photographs.
content: Before the advent of drones, people had to rely mostly on airplanes or helicopters to take aerial photographs. Now, thanks to increasing availability and decreasing price points of drones, as well as advances in obstacle avoidance technology, GPS navigation, battery life and camera stabilization, it certainly seems easier to take photographs from higher elevations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Dysfunction Reigns in Congress as G.O.P. Defeats Multiply
description: In a day of chaos in the Capitol, Republicans failed to impeach the homeland security secretary, lost a vote to speed aid to Israel and cheered the demise of a border deal they had demanded.
content: Republicans in Congress suffered a humiliating series of setbacks on Tuesday on critical elements of their agenda, turning the Capitol into a den of dysfunction that has left several major issues, including U.S. military aid to Ukraine and Israel, in limbo amid political feuding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Formal Dining Shows What It Can Do at Café Carmellini
description: You thought Old World opulence was over? A prolific chef gives it a new and very personal spin.
content: The formal, European style of restaurant service was perfected in the 19th century, was stiff as a corpse by the end of the 20th and seemed safely buried by the early days of the pandemic. But it won’t stay dead. It is in full swing at Essential by Christophe, Torrisi Bar & Restaurant, Oiji Mi and Café Boulud, all of which have opened in New York City since 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford Reports Quarterly Loss but Says Sales Grew
description: Ford Motor attributed the loss in the fourth quarter to charges related to pension plans and a restructuring of overseas operations.
content: Ford Motor said it lost $526 million in the final three months of 2023, mainly as a result of special charges related to its employee pension programs and the reorganization of some of its overseas operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Meta Calls for Industry Effort to Label A.I.-Generated Content
description: The social network wants to promote standardized labels to help detect artificially created photo, video and audio material across its platforms.
content: Last month at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Nick Clegg, president of global affairs at Meta, called a nascent effort to detect artificially generated content “the most urgent task” facing the tech industry today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Toby Keith Was More Than Mere Bluster
description: His choice to become a post-9/11 culture-war champion overshadowed the work of a musician who was funnier, subtler and more politically slippery than his most famous work let on.
content: It is important to note right from the beginning that Toby Keith, when presented with the opportunity to become the music industry’s jingoist-in-chief, leaned in. At the turn of the millennium, just after the Sept. 11 attacks, Keith, who died Monday at 62, released a string of songs that were notable for their political stridency, commitment to American exceptionalism and flexed-bicep threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: Judge in Trump’s Civil Fraud Case Asks Whether a Key Witness Lied
description: The Trump Organization’s ex-finance chief is negotiating a possible perjury plea. Justice Arthur Engoron is considering how that should affect the former president’s punishment.
content: The judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud case has questioned whether a key witness committed perjury during the former president’s trial, a new court filing shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Madden
title: But What Do the Tortured Poets Think?
description: The title of Taylor Swift’s next album, “The Tortured Poets Department,” spurred strong responses from a typically quiet bunch.
content: When Taylor Swift announced the title of her next album during an acceptance speech at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, she spurred a reaction from a typically quiet bunch: the poets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Threatens to Veto Bill That Would Help Israel but Not Ukraine
description: President Biden accused Republicans in the House of a “cynical political maneuver” intended to kill broader legislation that would also provide money for the southern border.
content: President Biden vowed on Monday to veto a House Republican bill that would provide $17.6 billion in aid to Israel, calling it a “cynical political maneuver” intended to hurt the chances of passage for broader legislation that would provide money for Israel, Ukraine, Taiwan and the U.S. border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Toby Keith, Larger-Than-Life Country Music Star, Dies at 62
description: He cultivated an in-your-face persona with hits like “Who’s Your Daddy?” and “Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue.” He announced in 2022 that he had cancer.
content: Toby Keith, the larger-than-life singer-songwriter of No. 1 country hits like “Who’s Your Daddy?” and “Made in America” and one of the biggest stars to come out of Nashville in three decades, died on Monday. He was 62.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Federal Appeals Court Rejects Trump’s Claim of Absolute Immunity
description: The ruling answered a question that an appeals court had never addressed: Can former presidents escape being held accountable by the criminal justice system for things they did while in office?
content: A federal appeals court on Tuesday rejected former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he was immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to subvert the results of the 2020 election, ruling that he must go to trial on a criminal indictment accusing him of seeking to overturn his loss to President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Nereim
title: Houthi Attacks and U.S.-Led Strikes Dash Hopes for Quick Yemen Peace Deal
description: A U.N.-backed process to end Yemen’s nine-year conflict appeared to be moving forward recently. But then the war in Gaza began and tensions spilled over.
content: For nine years, Yemen was torn by a war that erupted when the Houthis, a Yemeni militia supported by Iran, ousted the government and took control of the country’s northwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: What to Watch in Nevada’s Weird Election Week
description: Tuesday’s primaries feature President Biden with token opposition, while Nikki Haley is aiming not to lose to “none of these candidates.” G.O.P. caucuses, engineered for Donald Trump, are on Thursday.
content: The bifurcated Republican presidential nomination contest that is unfolding this week in Nevada — a nonbinding primary on Tuesday and caucuses on Thursday — was orchestrated by Republican leaders to assure another delegate victory for Donald J. Trump in his march to the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Biden Criticizes Republicans for Blocking Bill With Aid for Israel and Gaza
description: Senators from both parties shaped the legislation, which links a crackdown on unlawful migration to delivering emergency aid to war-torn areas overseas.
content: President Biden criticized Republican lawmakers on Tuesday for attempting to thwart bipartisan legislation that would overhaul the nation’s immigration system and, among other things, authorize billions of dollars in aid for Israel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Southern California Braces for Potential Mudslides as Rain Continues
description: Weather experts warned that additional rain on top of saturated soil in the Los Angeles region could still cause hillsides to collapse.
content: A ferocious atmospheric river storm that has battered California for days began to taper off in Los Angeles on Tuesday, but officials warned that even small amounts of additional precipitation could set off landslides in rain-drenched Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: Mammals With the Munchies: Curing Animals With Cannabis
description: While many people and their doctors have embraced medical marijuana for health ills, treating pets and zoo animals with CBD and THC is just beginning.
content: Like many captive elephants, Nidia suffered from chronic foot problems. Fissures had formed in the 55-year-old Asian elephant’s foot pads, and her toenails had cracked and become ingrown. Painful abscesses lingered for months. Nidia had lost her appetite and she was losing weight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Seizures of Psychedelic Mushrooms Rise in U.S. as Demand Grows
description: Psychoactive mushrooms, illegal under federal law, are gaining popularity as therapy tools. Some experts worry that the market is growing faster than the research.
content: Seizures of psychedelic mushrooms across the nation by law enforcement officials have increased significantly in recent years as attitudes regarding their use have grown more permissive, according to a government-funded study released Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump Pardon Recipient Fined $20 Million in Predatory Lending Case
description: Jonathan Braun, whose sentence for drug smuggling was commuted in the final hours of the Trump presidency, was fined over separate accusations that he bilked and threatened borrowers.
content: When President Donald J. Trump, in his final hours in the White House in early 2021, commuted a 10-year drug smuggling sentence being served by a New Yorker named Jonathan Braun, he made no mention of Mr. Braun’s many other legal problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Shteamer
title: A Timeline of Toby Keith’s Biggest Songs and Career Moments
description: The singer-songwriter was known for anthems, and political stances, that alternated between confrontation and big-tent populism.
content: Toby Keith first drew recognition beyond country music as the artist behind the divisive post-9/11 rallying cry “Courtesy of the Red, White and Blue (The Angry American).” But the singer-songwriter, who died Monday at the age of 62 after a battle with stomach cancer, appeared to view himself as a unifying force. “As far extreme as I seem,” he said in 2003, “I’m probably catching the average Joe in the middle better than anybody.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Group in Michigan Urges Protest Vote Against Biden Over Israel-Gaza War
description: The Democratic group is telling voters to mark “Uncommitted” on their primary ballots.
content: A group of Democrats in Michigan is urging voters unhappy with President Biden’s approach to the war between Israel and Hamas to vote for Uncommitted on the state’s Feb. 27 primary ballots to demonstrate a frustration that Mr. Biden has not demanded a cease-fire in the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: Is the Middle-Class Dream Over in Las Vegas?
description: Many voters in Nevada dislike the Republican Party, but they also wonder if Democrats in Washington are too old and out of touch to fight for them.
content: To many Americans, Las Vegas is a burst of glittering hotels and seedy wedding chapels, a mirage-like city rising improbably from the Mojave Desert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Endless Range, Boundless Swagger: Why Caitlin Clark Is Different
description: Her fiery competitiveness, no-look passes and 3-point bombs have made for must-see basketball in Iowa. What happens when she leaves?
content: When Caitlin Clark moves — weaving through defensive traffic; waving unsubtly for a teammate’s pass; wriggling free enough to catch, fire, catch fire — people tend to follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: U.S. Ambassadors in the Pacific Urge Action on Ukraine, Israel and Border Bill
description: With the package teetering on the brink of collapse, diplomats said the nation’s credibility was on the line.
content: A group of U.S. ambassadors stationed in the Indo-Pacific region is urging congressional leaders to secure passage of legislation providing assistance to Ukraine, Israel and allies in the Pacific, saying America’s credibility with its strategic partners is on the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Dartmouth Players Are Employees Who Can Unionize, U.S. Official Says
description: A regional director for the National Labor Relations Board cleared the way for the collegiate men’s basketball team to hold a vote.
content: A federal official said Monday that members of the Dartmouth men’s basketball team were university employees, clearing a path for the team to take a vote that could make it the first unionized college sports program in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘You Are Meant to Be With a Woman’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: I eat an egg, over-easy, every morning. In the summer, I make the egg myself. As a teacher, my mornings are slower during those months. It tastes fine. But during the school year, my husband makes the egg every morning. Same stove. Same pan. Same ingredients. Yet his egg is unbelievably delicious. Is it cliché to say the secret ingredient is love? Is it my love for him that makes the egg so good, or his love for me? Probably both. I think he uses more butter, too. — Jackie Hostetler
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Republican Impeachment of Mayorkas Fails Amid G.O.P. Defections
description: In a stunning defeat, the House rejected impeachment charges against the homeland security secretary, as rank-and-file lawmakers balked at what they considered a misuse of the process.
content: The United States House of Representatives on Tuesday defeated impeachment charges against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, after a small group of Republicans broke with their party and refused to support what amounted to a partisan indictment of President Biden’s immigration policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: More Than a Fifth of Hostages in Gaza Are Dead, Israel Says
description: As Israel and Hamas inch closer to a deal to free hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners and a cease-fire, the military disclosed that at least 30 of the captives still in Gaza have been confirmed dead.
content: Israel has called securing the freedom of the hostages abducted to Gaza a key goal in its war against Hamas, so many in the country were shocked on Tuesday when it emerged that at least a fifth of the captives were already dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: How Anger Over School Cuts Fuels Debate Over Mayoral Control
description: It’s up to the Legislature to decide whether to renew mayoral control of schools. This year, tweaks in the system could happen.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at whether Mayor Eric Adams should retain control of the public school system in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisy Lafarge
title: A Scottish Coming-of-Age Story, With a Supernatural Twist
description: In Margot Livesey’s new novel, “The Road From Belhaven,” a 19th-century farm girl’s life and maturity are complicated by her uncontrollable visions of accident and disaster.
content: Lizzie Craig has a gift: She sees “pictures” of events before they take place. It happens first when she’s 10, with a vision in which her grandfather’s scythe slips from a whetstone and injures his leg. It’s the tail end of the 19th century in Fife, rural Scotland, where Lizzie is brought up by her grandparents on Belhaven Farm. Her pictures, more often than not, are premonitions of accidents and disasters: a hurt leg, a wheel coming off a cart, a tree hit by lightning. They tend to arrive “a few weeks before the accident,” giving Lizzie time to prepare, and sometimes, intervene accordingly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Why Eating Disorder Content Keeps Spreading
description: TikTok shut down the “legging legs” hashtag, but experts said they’re more worried about other content surfaced by social media algorithms.
content: In late January, a volunteer at the help line for the National Alliance for Eating Disorders fielded a call from someone who had seen an alarming trend on TikTok. The hashtag #legginglegs had started taking off as users posted about the slim bodies seemingly deemed the most desirable for leggings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley, Facing Rising Threats, Requests Secret Service Protection
description: Ms. Haley, who is battling Donald Trump for the Republican nomination, has had two “swatting” attempts reported at her home.
content: Nikki Haley, who has been the target of at least two hoax calls that have sent the authorities rushing to her home, has applied for Secret Service protection as the number of threats against her has increased, a campaign spokeswoman confirmed Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: President Biden, in Speakerphone Call to Los Angeles Mayor, Promises Aid
description: Mayor Karen Bass had been updating residents on the state of the storm when the president suddenly called her. He praised the city’s efforts as “one hell of an operation.”
content: Mayor Karen Bass of Los Angeles was midway through a news conference on Monday evening, updating residents on the storm pummeling Los Angeles, when she suddenly stepped away from the microphone to take a phone call — from President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Fallon Reports ‘Today’s Taylor Swift News’
description: “If you thought she was on your TV a lot last night, well, wait till next Sunday,” Fallon said after the pop star’s big night at the Grammys.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BP to Increase Oil Output, New Chief Says
description: Murray Auchincloss signaled that he would take a more profit-oriented approach than his predecessor, who started a big push into renewables.
content: BP’s new chief executive, Murray Auchincloss, promised a flexible approach to the shift away from fossil fuels as the oil giant reported a $3 billion profit in its latest quarter on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Silky Salmon at the Push of a Button
description: Our new recipe for microwave salmon is already earning rave reviews: “I was skeptical when I first read this. But the salmon was perfect on the first try.”
content: The microwave and the baby arrived roughly around the same time. I hadn’t had a microwave until then: My kitchen was small, counter space was highly coveted and I wasn’t doing enough reheating to justify it. But my husband wisely realized that we’d want to heat food for the baby and for us, the new parents, in a quick and nonfussy way. And so it happened. We bought a microwave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: ‘Grinch Boys’ Charged With Robbing Clubgoers to Fund Shopping Sprees
description: Prosecutors said the green Dr. Seuss character the Grinch was the group’s mascot as members ran up five-figure bills at luxury stores in SoHo and beyond.
content: Manhattan prosecutors announced charges Tuesday against four people who they said targeted intoxicated clubgoers, stole their credit cards and phones and used them to purchase more than $400,000 worth of luxury goods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Claire Fahy
title: $2.4 Billion Is Not Enough for New York’s Migrant Crisis, Adams Says
description: Mayor Eric Adams told state lawmakers in Albany that New York City needed $4.6 billion just to pay for half of its yearly costs related to the migrant influx.
content: With the migrant crisis continuing to roil New York City, Mayor Eric Adams appeared to score a win last month when the governor vowed to commit $2.4 billion — more than double last year’s proposal — to cover the costs of caring for the tens of thousands of people who have arrived in New York to seek refuge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: An Arts Festival About Sports, for People Who Don’t Like Sports
description: A series of events in preparation for the Paris Olympics explores a paradox, since arts and sports rarely mix in France.
content: When it comes to the biggest sports show on earth, many Parisians have reached the stage of begrudging acceptance. The level of disruption — and metro price hikes — to get the city ready for this summer’s Olympic Games hasn’t exactly endeared the event to locals, especially those who favor culture over sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Couldn’t Shut Down the Border. Can Biden?
description: President Biden could take some steps without Congress, but the idea that he has unfettered power to seal off the country is far too simplistic.
content: President Biden is pleading with Congress for new authority to shut down the nation’s overwhelmed southern border, declaring that he has done “all I can do” and urging lawmakers to “give me the power” to fix it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: 7 Grammy Winners Worth Another Spin
description: Hear songs by Laufey, Jason Isbell, Samara Joy and more.
content: I can hardly believe I’m saying this, but this year’s Grammys were … really good?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Clyde Taylor, Literary Scholar Who Elevated Black Cinema, Dies at 92
description: A leading figure in the field of Black studies in the 1970s, he identified work by Black filmmakers as worthy of serious intellectual attention.
content: Clyde Taylor, a scholar who in the 1970s and ’80s played a leading role in identifying, defining and elevating Black cinema as an art form, died on Jan. 24 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew F. Delmont
title: What Democracy Looks Like in the Fight for Civil Rights
description: “John Lewis” and “Medgar and Myrlie” tell the stories of activists who struggled with when to push and when to compromise and build coalitions.
content: In the spring of 1961, John Lewis and Medgar Evers found themselves at odds with the leadership of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The N.A.A.C.P. executive secretary, Roy Wilkins, wanted Black freedom won through institutional channels: voter registration and the courts. As 21-year-old Lewis and the other young Freedom Riders prepared to set off by Greyhound for Mississippi that May, Wilkins fretted: What would their new allies in the White House think? He dismissed the journey as a “joy ride.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 6, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 6, 2024.
content: An article on Monday about a campaign to get a championship H.B.C.U. basketball team the recognition it deserves misspelled the surname of the Tennessee A&I Tigers basketball coach. He is John McLendon, not McClendon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Displaced Gazans Wonder Where to Go as Israel Vows to Keep Pushing South
description: Some in Rafah, in southern Gaza, were already dismantling their tents, packing their bags and fleeing. But it was unclear whether other areas would be safer.
content: Palestinians sheltering in crowded tent cities along the border between the Gaza Strip and Egypt were fearful on Tuesday after a senior Israeli minister reiterated that Israel’s ground invasion would extend to Rafah, the southernmost city in the enclave where hundreds of thousands of displaced people have ended up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: The G.O.P. Bumper Sticker: Trump First. Putin Second. America Third.
description: How the country and the world are defined is in Congress’s hands.
content: Every so often there is a piece of legislation on Capitol Hill that defines America and its values — that shows what kind of country we want to be. I would argue that when it comes to the $118.3 billion bipartisan compromise bill in the Senate to repair our broken immigration system and supply vital aid to Ukraine, Taiwan and Israel, its passage or failure won’t define just America but also the world that we’re going to inhabit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Texas Company Was Behind Voter Robocalls That Impersonated Biden, N.H. Says
description: The state attorney general said the calls, which used a voice that sounded like President Biden’s to discourage voting, originated with a company called Life Corporation.
content: The New Hampshire attorney general said on Tuesday that his office, alongside federal officials and other state attorneys general, had identified the company behind robocalls last month that used an impersonation of President Biden’s voice to urge Democrats not to vote in the state’s primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Who Says Historic Homes Have to Be Stuffy?
description: Here’s how one couple brought their Federal house in Salem, Mass., into the 21st century — with ‘color, character and eccentricity.’
content: Julia Lippman and Mathew Eapen love antique homes, but they’re not typical old-house enthusiasts — or purists when it comes to decorating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Blinken travels to Egypt and Qatar in his bid to avert a wider regional war.
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with leaders in Egypt and Qatar on Tuesday, the second day of a Middle East tour aimed at preventing an exchange of attacks with Iran-backed militias from spiraling into a broader regional war and to rally allies around a proposed cease-fire agreement for Gaza.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met with leaders in Egypt and Qatar on Tuesday, the second day of a Middle East tour aimed at preventing an exchange of attacks with Iran-backed militias from spiraling into a broader regional war and to rally allies around a proposed cease-fire agreement for Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Miller
title: When the Biggest Student Mental Health Advocates Are the Students
description: With the number of adolescents struggling with mental health rising, student-led clubs have come to provide support amid a dearth of resources.
content: Last October, to commemorate Mental Health Awareness Week, a group of students at Sacopee Valley High School in Hiram, Maine, created the annual Hope Board. Shaped like an enormous tulip and displayed in the lobby, the board was covered with anonymous teenage aspirations. Some students hoped to pass driver’s education or have a successful playoff season. Others expressed more complicated desires. “To be more happy than angry,” wrote one student. Another wrote, “I hope people are kinder and more mature.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Jim Rutenberg
title: Tucker Carlson Says He Will Soon Interview Putin
description: The Kremlin did not immediately confirm an interview with Mr. Carlson. It would be Mr. Putin’s first formal interview with Western media since the start of his full-scale invasion of Ukraine.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will “soon” sit for an interview with Tucker Carlson, the former Fox News host said on Tuesday, a sign that the Russian leader is seeking to make a direct appeal to American conservatives as U.S. aid to Ukraine hangs in the balance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Pochoda
title: A Speculative Jazz Age Noir Brimming With Murder and Conspiracy
description: In Francis Spufford’s new novel, “Cahokia Jazz,” a detective must solve the mystery of a staged killing before its repercussions destroy his city’s social and political order.
content: Reader, let me ask you a question. How much work are you willing to do to dive into a new novel? Do you want to step into a speculative world frustratingly close to our own? Do you want to spend time in an imaginary city constructed with the world-building minutiae of a high fantasy novel? Do you want to engage with new forms of government and religious sects? Are you cool if there’s foreign language peppered throughout? How about the Klan? A Red scare? A nascent F.B.I.? A love story? Do you also want jazz? And do you want all of this to be part of a detective novel?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: An Appeals Court Rejected Trump’s Claim of Immunity
description: Also, Biden pushes for a faltering border deal. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: A panel of three federal appeals court judges today unanimously rejected Donald Trump’s claim that he was immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to subvert the results of the 2020 election because he was president at the time. The judges ruled that he was subject to federal criminal law and must stand trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: A New Bill Could Bring ‘Social Housing’ to New York
description: The bill would create a state agency to build developments that would be affordable but wouldn’t rely wholly on public subsidies.
content: The left-leaning wing of the Democratic Party has long favored rent control and eviction bans to address New York’s housing crisis. Now, progressives in the state also want to revive an old concept: let the government develop thousands of affordable homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Amarena, on the Upper East Side, Is Julian Medina’s Ode to Italy
description: Demo from two Wildair alumni, Sanuki Udon with more than a dozen types of noodles and more restaurant news.
content: Against the odds, the chef Julian Medina is an optimist when it comes to the business of owning restaurants. Just this past year he opened three, and he is about to add another for a total of 12 at various levels of service and price. The newest one, open later this week, is his first that is not rooted in his native Mexico or even Cuba, like his Cuban-style diner, Coppelia. It is Italian. “My cooking background is French, my restaurants are Mexican but there’s a place in my heart for Italian,” he said. “I’m ready to cook my own interpretation.” His ode to Italy, named for the Italian sour cherry, looks to Roman cooking and that of coastal areas. It has moved into the Upper East Side townhouse space occupied until last year by the Simone. But unlike the garden-level predecessor, his restaurant, with 60 seats, will occupy two floors and will add a bar in the almost summery setting with light colors accented with green downstairs. Upstairs, a more opulent room is done in a ruby palette; both areas will offer the same menu. Louis Skibar, a frequent partner, is a co-owner. To begin, the restaurant will serve dinner featuring various supplì, like arancini; baked clams with salsa verde; bucatini carbonara with duck guanciale and duck eggs; pappardelle with Sunday gravy and beef cheeks; and suckling pig agrodolce. Soon, there will be breakfast with panini and classic Italian pastries like sfogliatelle, and lunch. The wine list is all Italian.
